prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The CO(4-3) line falls for galaxy 1, 2, 4 and 5 in band 3. With this first observation, we center the first two basebands ontop of CO(4-3) for galaxies 1 and 2 at 114 and 112 GHz, with native resolutions of 2.5km/s. Given the expected line FWHM~300km/s, we smooth the native channels to a width of 20km/s. The other two channels are devoted to detecting the continuum in regions as contiguous as possible to the CO lines.

Our galaxies have typical diameters of 2 arcsec, so they could be in principle resolved by ALMA. However, high spatial resolution is not a main goal of this proposal, so we decided not to ask for resolution below 0.6" (higher spatial resolution would need more integration time).

We estimated the expected CO fluxes for our galaxies by scaling the sub-mm 250-350 rest-frame detections into total molecular gas mass following the prescription in Groves et al. (2013). The molecular gas masses are then converted in C(1-0) fluxes using the classical MW conversion for normal star forming galaxies (Solomon&Vanden Bout 2005). Then, we apply CO SLED conversions to scale the CO(1-0) flux to C(4-3) flux (Weiss et al. 2007; also Carilli et al. 2013). By doing so, we obtain S(CO4-3)dV= 4.6 and 7.7 Jykm/s for galaxy 1 and 2, respectively. Assuming a FWHM of 300km/s, typical for galaxies of similar stellar masses at those redshifts, we obtain peak fluxes of 15 and 26 mJy for galaxy 1 and 2, respectively. With the required sensitivity of 1mJy, we can sample the line with S/N~10 over several 20km/s channels.
We note however that assuming a starburst conversion between total gas mass would give fainter CO fluxes, by around a factor of 5. However, as we show in the scientific justification, our galaxies lie on the main sequence, and so it is reasonable to assume that the MW conversion is the correct one to assume. Moreover, also the conversion of sub-mm 250mum fluxes to total molecular mass has a 50% uncertainty: the prescription in Scoville et al. 2013 would give total gas masses that are 40% lower. Taking these two uncertainties into account, we estimate that even if the CO fluxes were a factor of 3 lower, we still would be able to detect the line with S/N~5 over several independent 20km/s channels. In case the fluxes were even lower, we will reduce the spectral resolution to increase the S/N.

The CO(4-3) line falls for galaxy 1, 2, 4 and 5 in band 3. With this second observation, we center the first two basebands ontop of CO(4-3) for galaxies 4 and 5 at 106 and 104 GHz, with native resoltuions of ~2.5km/s. Given the expected line FWHM~300km/s, we smooth the native channels to a width of ~20km/s. The other two channels are devoted to detecting the continuum in regions as contiguous as possible to the CO lines.

Our galaxies have typical diameters of 2 arcsec, so they could be in principle resolved by ALMA. However, high spatial resolution is not a main goal of this proposal, so we decided not to ask for resolution below 0.6" (higher spatial resolution would need more integration time).

We estimated the expected CO fluxes for our galaxies by scaling the sub-mm 250-350 rest-frame detections into total molecular gas mass following the prescription in Groves et al. (2013). The molecular gas masses are then converted in C(1-0) fluxes using the classical MW conversion for normal star forming galaxies (Solomon&Vanden Bout 2005). Then, we apply CO SLED conversions to scale the CO(1-0) flux to C(4-3) flux (Weiss et al. 2007; also Carilli et al. 2013). By doing so, we obtain S(CO4-3)dV=6 and 6.3 Jykm/s for galaxy 4 and 5, respectively. Assuming a FWHM of 300km/s, typical for galaxies of similar stellar masses at those redshifts, we obtain peak fluxes of 20 and 21 mJy for galaxy 4 and 5, respectively. With the required sensitivity of 1mJy, we can sample the line with S/N~10 over several 20km/s channels.
We note however that assuming a starburst conversion between total gas mass would give fainter CO fluxes, by around a factor of 5. However, as we show in the scientific justification, our galaxies lie on the main sequence, and so it is reasonable to assume that the MW conversion is the correct one to assume. Moreover, also the conversion of sub-mm 250mum fluxes to total molecular mass has a 50% uncertainty: the prescription in Scoville et al. 2013 would give total gas masses that are 40% lower. Taking these two uncertainties into account, we estimate that even if the CO fluxes were a factor of 3 lower, we still would be able to detect the line with S/N~5 over several independent 20km/s channels. In case the fluxes were even lower, we will reduce the spectral resolution to increase the S/N.

The CO(4-3) line falls for galaxy 3 at a frequency not covered by ALMA. So, we decided to target CO(3-2) instead. With this third observation, we center the one baseband ontop of CO(3-2) for galaxy 3 at 88GHz, with native resoltuions of ~3km/s. Given the expected line FWHM~300km/s, we smooth the native channels to a width of ~25km/s. The other three channels are devoted to detecting the continuum in regions as contiguous as possible to the CO line.

Our galaxies have typical diameters of 2 arcsec, so they could be in principle resolved by ALMA. However, high spatial resolution is not a main goal of this proposal, so we decided not to ask for resolution below 0.6" (higher spatial resolution would need more integration time).

We estimated the expected CO fluxes for our galaxies by scaling the sub-mm 250-350 rest-frame detections into total molecular gas mass following the prescription in Groves et al. (2013). The molecular gas masses are then converted in C(1-0) fluxes using the classical MW conversion for normal star forming galaxies (Solomon&Vanden Bout 2005). Then, we apply CO SLED conversions to scale the CO(1-0) flux to C(4-3) flux (Weiss et al. 2007; also Carilli et al. 2013). By doing so, we obtain S(CO3-2)dV= 4.5 Jykm/s for galaxy 3. Assuming a FWHM of 300km/s, typical for galaxies of similar stellar masses at those redshifts, we obtain peak flux of 15 mJy. With the required sensitivity of 1mJy, we can sample the line with S/N~10 over several 20km/s channels.
We note however that assuming a starburst conversion between total gas mass would give fainter CO fluxes, by around a factor of 5. However, as we show in the scientific justification, our galaxies lie on the main sequence, and so it is reasonable to assume that the MW conversion is the correct one to assume. Moreover, also the conversion of sub-mm 250mum fluxes to total molecular mass has a 50% uncertainty: the prescription in Scoville et al. 2013 would give total gas masses that are 40% lower. Taking these two uncertainties into account, we estimate that even if the CO flux were a factor of 3 lower, we still would be able to detect the line with S/N~5 over several independent 20km/s channels. In case the flux were even lower, we will reduce the spectral resolution to increase the S/N.

The CO(5-4) line falls for all galaxies in band 4. With this observation, we center the first two basebands ontop of CO(5-4) for galaxies 1 and 2 at 141 and 142 GHz, with native resoltuions of ~2.km/s. Given the expected line FWHM~300km/s, we smooth the native channels to a width of ~20km/s. The other two channels are devoted to detecting the continuum in regions as contiguous as possible to the CO lines.

Our galaxies have typical diameters of 2 arcsec, so they could be in principle resolved by ALMA. However, high spatial resolution is not a main goal of this proposal, so we decided not to ask for resolution below 0.6" (higher spatial resolution would need more integration time).

Since constraining the SLED between CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) (for 4 galaxies; between CO(5-4) and CO(3-2) for one) is a goal of this proposal, we decided to target the same S(CO)_peak sensitivity for the two transitions. For the same reason, we also assume a flat SLED between the two transitions, and we thus provide the OT with the same peak fluxes for CO(5-4) here that we have assumed for CO(4-3).
We estimated the expected CO fluxes for our galaxies by scaling the sub-mm 250-350 rest-frame detections into total molecular gas mass following the prescription in Groves et al. (2013). The molecular gas masses are then converted in C(1-0) fluxes using the classical MW conversion for normal star forming galaxies (Solomon&Vanden Bout 2005). Then, we apply CO SLED conversions to scale the CO(1-0) flux to C(4-3) flux (Weiss et al. 2007; also Carilli et al. 2013). By doing so, we obtain S(CO4-3)dV= 4.6 and 7.7 Jykm/s for galaxy 1 and 2, respectively (and we assume the same fluxes for CO(5-4) here for the purpose of the estimation of the integration time). Assuming a FWHM of 300km/s, typical for galaxies of similar stellar masses at those redshifts, we obtain peak fluxes of 15 and 26 mJy for galaxy 1 and 2, respectively. With the required sensitivity of 1mJy, we can sample the line with S/N~10 over several 20km/s channels.
We note however that assuming a starburst conversion between total gas mass would give fainter CO fluxes, by around a factor of 5. However, as we show in the scientific justification, our galaxies lie on the main sequence, and so it is reasonable to assume that the MW conversion is the correct one to assume. Moreover, also the conversion of sub-mm 250mum fluxes to total molecular mass has a 50% uncertainty: the prescription in Scoville et al. 2013 would give total gas masses that are 40% lower. Taking these two uncertainties into account, we estimate that even if the CO fluxes were a factor of 3 lower, we still would be able to detect the line with S/N~5 over several independent 20km/s channels. In case the fluxes were even lower, we will reduce the spectral resolution to increase the S/N.
We note also that normal and starburst galaxies have typically higher fluxes for CO(5-4) than CO(4-3), by a factor of 1.5 and 2.5, respectively (Daddi et al. 2015). This would imply that we expect even higher CO(5-4) fluxes and S/N than for CO(4-3), and this effect mitigates almost completely the uncertainty on the molecular-mass-to-CO-fluxes conversion factor to apply.

The CO(5-4) line falls for all galaxies in band 4. With this observation, we center the first two basebands ontop of CO(5-4) for galaxies 4 and 5 at 130 and 133 GHz, with native resolutions of ~2.km/s. Given the expected line FWHM~300km/s, we smooth the native channels to a width of ~20km/s. The other two channels are devoted to detecting the continuum in regions as contiguous as possible to the CO lines.

Our galaxies have typical diameters of 2 arcsec, so they could be in principle resolved by ALMA. However, high spatial resolution is not a main goal of this proposal, so we decided not to ask for resolution below 0.6" (higher spatial resolution would need more integration time).

Since constraining the SLED between CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) (for 4 galaxies; between CO(5-4) and CO(3-2) for one) is a goal of this proposal, we decided to target the same S(CO)_peak sensitivity for the two transitions. For the same reason, we also assume a flat SLED between the two transitions, and we thus provide the OT with the same peak fluxes for CO(5-4) here that we have assumed for CO(4-3).
We estimated the expected CO fluxes for our galaxies by scaling the sub-mm 250-350 rest-frame detections into total molecular gas mass following the prescription in Groves et al. (2013). The molecular gas masses are then converted in C(1-0) fluxes using the classical MW conversion for normal star forming galaxies (Solomon&Vanden Bout 2005). Then, we apply CO SLED conversions to scale the CO(1-0) flux to C(4-3) flux (Weiss et al. 2007; also Carilli et al. 2013). By doing so, we obtain S(CO4-3)dV= 6 and 6.3 Jykm/s for galaxy 1 and 2, respectively (and we assume the same fluxes for CO(5-4) here for the purpose of the estimation of the integration time). Assuming a FWHM of 300km/s, typical for galaxies of similar stellar masses at those redshifts, we obtain peak fluxes of 21 and 20 mJy for galaxy 1 and 2, respectively. With the required sensitivity of 1mJy, we can sample the line with S/N~10 over several 20km/s channels.
We note however that assuming a starburst conversion between total gas mass would give fainter CO fluxes, by around a factor of 5. However, as we show in the scientific justification, our galaxies lie on the main sequence, and so it is reasonable to assume that the MW conversion is the correct one to assume. Moreover, also the conversion of sub-mm 250mum fluxes to total molecular mass has a 50% uncertainty: the prescription in Scoville et al. 2013 would give total gas masses that are 40% lower. Taking these two uncertainties into account, we estimate that even if the CO fluxes were a factor of 3 lower, we still would be able to detect the line with S/N~5 over several independent 20km/s channels. In case the fluxes were even lower, we will reduce the spectral resolution to increase the S/N.
We note also that normal and starburst galaxies have typically higher fluxes for CO(5-4) than CO(4-3), by a factor of 1.5 and 2.5, respectively (Daddi et al. 2015). This would imply that we expect even higher CO(5-4) fluxes and S/N than for CO(4-3), and this effect mitigates almost completely the uncertainty on the molecular-mass-to-CO-fluxes conversion factor to apply.

The CO(5-4) line falls for all galaxies in band 4. With this observation, we center the first two basebands ontop of CO(5-4) for galaxies 3 at 147 GHz, with native resoltuions of ~2.km/s. Given the expected line FWHM~300km/s, we smooth the native channels to a width of ~20km/s. The other two channels are devoted to detecting the continuum in regions as contiguous as possible to the CO lines.

Our galaxies have typical diameters of 2 arcsec, so they could be in principle resolved by ALMA. However, high spatial resolution is not a main goal of this proposal, so we decided not to ask for resolution below 0.6" (higher spatial resolution would need more integration time).

Since constraining the SLED between CO(5-4) and CO(4-3) (for galaxies 1,2,4 and 5; between CO(5-4) and CO(3-2) for galaxy 3) is a goal of this proposal, we decided to target the same S(CO)_peak sensitivity for the two transitions. For the same reason, we also assume a flat SLED between the two transitions, and we thus provide the OT with the same peak fluxes for CO(5-4) here that we have assumed for CO(4-3).
We estimated the expected CO fluxes for our galaxies by scaling the sub-mm 250-350 rest-frame detections into total molecular gas mass following the prescription in Groves et al. (2013). The molecular gas masses are then converted in C(1-0) fluxes using the classical MW conversion for normal star forming galaxies (Solomon&Vanden Bout 2005). Then, we apply CO SLED conversions to scale the CO(1-0) flux to C(3-2) flux (Weiss et al. 2007; also Carilli et al. 2013). By doing so, we obtain S(CO4-3)dV= 4.5 Jykm/s for galaxy 3 (and we assume the same flux for CO(5-4) here for the purpose of the estimation of the integration time). Assuming a FWHM of 300km/s, typical for galaxies of similar stellar masses at those redshifts, we obtain peak fluxes of 15 mJy. With the required sensitivity of 1 mJy, we can sample the line with S/N~10 over several 20km/s channels.
We note however that assuming a starburst conversion between total gas mass would give fainter CO fluxes, by around a factor of 5. However, as we show in the scientific justification, our galaxies lie on the main sequence, and so it is reasonable to assume that the MW conversion is the correct one to assume. Moreover, also the conversion of sub-mm 250mum fluxes to total molecular mass has a 50% uncertainty: the prescription in Scoville et al. 2013 would give total gas masses that are 40% lower. Taking these two uncertainties into account, we estimate that even if the CO fluxes were a factor of 3 lower, we still would be able to detect the line with S/N~5 over several independent 20km/s channels. In case the fluxes were even lower, we will reduce the spectral resolution to increase the S/N.
We note also that normal and starburst galaxies have typically higher fluxes for CO(5-4) than CO(4-3), by a factor of 1.5 and 2.5, respectively (Daddi et al. 2015). This would imply that we expect even higher CO(5-4) fluxes and S/N than for CO(4-3), and this effect mitigates almost completely the uncertainty on the molecular-mass-to-CO-fluxes conversion factor to apply.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The goal of this proposal is to unveil the nature of 5 normal main sequence star-forming galaxies at 3<z<3.5 with strong detections at 240GHz with ALMA (high rest-frame 250mum luminosities) by probing the properties of their reservoirs of dense molecular gas. In particular, we will estimate the CO SLED between CO(5-4) and a lower CO transition (J=4-3 for 4 objects; J=3-2 for one) to constrain the source of the CO excitation. We will then estimate the total dynamical mass of the galaxies from the width of the CO lines. Finally, we will constrain the total molecular content of the galaxies, measuring gas fractions, dust-to-gas ratios (from 250mum continuum) and gas depletion times in a redshift range not yet explored by normal unlensed galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
